".... I just thought you needed some help." Trent mumbles, jolted by the strange customer. Some people obviously need their privacy - this one was one of those. Besides, hot or not, I ain't dealing with one of those women again. Angela was damn fine enough! Remembering her, he shivered slightly, but then refocused quickly to his work. An old woman, dumpy, stringy old carrot-hair, was meandering around the shoes. I know her, Trent thought, straightening up, and getting back into his groove. I just don't exactly know her name. Uh, hell. Miss, or Ma'am, that's a universal word, ain't it? She sure was confused, as usual. With one last sideways glance at the odd woman, he walked over to his real customer and began helping her out.

"Why hello, Ma'am, is there anything in particular that i can help you find?"" He suavely proposed to the little old woman.
"Why, hello again Samuel." I still don't where she gets that name from, but as long as it ain't from her old dead husband, I guess I can live with it. "I'm looking for some comfortable shoes, my pair are getting a little raggedy, is there any here that are comfortable?"
"Why, of course Ma'am! We've got a wide range of selections devoted to the most comfortable pairs of..." Of course, it was then that I got interrupted right in the middle of my speech. The speech never failed, and if I couldn't deliver it, who knows what will happen to her senile mind. I glared over to the tap I just received, to see that crazy gal standing right next to me. She looked like a junkie or something, a sense of want in her eyes. Of need. I can see her tremble and all and I wondered what the hell she wanted.

"Alright. I'm ready for your help." I just looked at her and laughed. My help? Girl, my help was on sale for one time only. It's off the shelves now. I wanted to turn my head and continue talking to my client, but it didn't look like she'd go away that easily. None of her type ever did.

"Just what do you think you're doing, miss? I'm afraid I'm with another customer, could you please hold on and I can be with you in..." I tried to calm the frantic girl down.
"No! No, I ain't got time for that! This is important." What a damn ... important? Who does she think she is? I looked over at the old lady, she had a worried look in her eyeglasses, she looked just like they do before they say "I'm fine, actually," I didn't want to lose her! So, I took this other one aside,

"Listen, miss. It's clothes. Clothes can wait, now so can you. I'll be with you in just a second."
"No. This isn't about clothes..." She said in her odd melodramatic voice. Right then I could feel relief welling up inside me. I laughed her off and turned back to my actual customer, but she kept going on..

"It's about the end of the world!" She screamed out in a screechy whisper. I put my head down, too embarrassed to be talking to this person. Then picked it up to see how my customer was doing. Damn!! She looked scared! That damn crazy witch has gotten her scared! I could hear those words coming right at me like a bullet,

"Um. Samuel, I can come back. I think you two need to talk..." And there she went. Oh well, it's just a customer. The worst part will be talking with this nut job! Turning around, I glared straight into her horrified eyes. Witch! I'll smack the fear out of your eyes... that's what I felt. But what I said was,

"The end of the world?"
"Yeah." She was serious. Dead serious, like one of those bums with the "Apocalypse is Coming" signs on outside. She was odd though, because she did this with her beauty. What a damn waste, I thought as I looked into her perfect green eyes. I didn't really want to talk with her anymore. It was almost closing time, and I was already tired of her. Then again, what the hell do I have to lose, I guess...

"I'm not crazy. This is real." She insisted again, I couldn't help but chuckle.
"Alright then, what's it all about? Second coming? Zombie outbreak? What in the hell is the problem with the Earth now?"
"Aliens ..." Aliens. Little green men, and bug eyed slimy creatures. I had an uncle who used to read these weird comic books to us each night. Brother Joey really got a kick out of them. They bored me a bit. In fact, this whole situation was starting to bore me. I was a no nonsense kind of guy,and this story already sounded like a waste of my time. But, I didn't follow my better judgment. I waltzed on over to a little chair and sat down for this yarn.
"From Mars?" I asked, with a mischievous little grin.
"No ... I don't know from where though."
"Well, then in theory, can't they be from Mars?"
"Well, yeah ... but! Where they're from doesn't matter! They're here! I saw them with my own eyes..." She really was beautiful. Rosy red lips, lovely tanned skin, too bad she was so..
"... I was with my friends Gracie and Janet down at Janet's dad's place. And there it was ... all of a sudden there was ... was this thing! It had barely any torso, and a small head. It's arms and legs were monstrous. Me and Gracie grabbed each other as we saw ..." She stopped her tale there. She looked as though she were about to cry. I couldn't help but feel sorry for the poor misguided weirdo.
"... it shot this gun that ... turned Mr, Peterson inside out..!"
"Must've been some mess to clean up" I almost laughed but stopped as I saw the look across her face. Even for a fable this one was eerie. This girl had talent with words.
"We ran ... we got separated. I went to the city ... to find help. She went ... I don't really know. But before we split up,she told me what Janet had told her. That they were controlling our minds .. the aliens, I think. It had gotten me and Gracie. The only thing that can stop it ... is DLC." DLC, I believe, little lady, you've mixed up the d for t, and in this case I would be...
"You know what that is?"
"No. I don't... You're going to tell me aren't you?" I laughed.
"Diamond-like-carbon. Mr. Peterson said the military had tested it and it was the only thing strong enough to withstand the kinds of waves they send out. That's why I'm here. I need to find some DLC."

Hmm. Lovely story and all, I smiled at her. Boy, she was no fun at all, even for a psycho. You expected at least a little ... aw well. I guess if that's what she believed in. That was alright with me, as long as she didn't ruin anymore of my...

"Will you help me?" I looked deep into her troubled eyes, and said,
"Sure. You want me to drive you to a hospital so that they can..."
"No!" She yelled, just like before. The boring phase looked like it was over. Time for the crazy, screaming one again. I looked around the place, hoping that they didn't see me hanging around with this banshee.
"I thought you were different! I thought you could help me fight these aliens!"
"Why?" She looked at me as if I had said something stupid. It was a legitimate question.
"Because ... You ... you kinda remind me of a friend I have ... and because you don't seem hypnotized." Aww. How sweet of her. Who cares? Does she really think i'm going to go running around yelling "The end is near!". No. It was getting late, and I was officially off the clock. She gazed at me with sparkling eyes, and a puppy dog pout. But, cute or not, that was just crazy ... wasn't it?

"Great!" She lit up like a damn light bulb; she really got a kick out of this kind of stuff didn't she? Well, I guess I could humor her a bit. I didn't see how in the hell she could be right, but she wasn't exactly a boring person, at least when she stopped all that crying and yelling. But then, I thought about the consequences that might ensue from dating a crazy girl like her. Yelling, crying, slapping. Er. I hated slapping. I took another look at her, but those glossy lips told me that maybe it wouldn't be all bad. Enjoy the ride, I suppose.

"Let's go!" In moments she had been jerking me by the arm like I was some sort of doll. Damn, girl! What a grip she had too! Things were looking less and less likely that she would take off that whole bossy, controlling attitude and be a sweet and gentle creature, ready for the Trentster to give her some sugar. But what could I do now, I had told the girl I'd help her, and I was a man of my word, if nothing else. Sure the exes would say otherwise, but they're bitter.

While we whizzed by the fat, lazy, boring blurs of the crowd I couldn't help but feel embarrassed. I usually did the tugging. In fact, no self respecting cat could sit by while she pulled on him. So I said something to her,

"Listen, babe, could you loosen up a bit, I think I'm starting to ..."
"What? Sorry, I can't hear you over this damn crowd!" Come on now! They weren't even that loud. Was she deaf? That was it, I was getting tired of all of this mess. Checking my new watch I could see how late it was, normally I'd be leaving by now.

"Oh! My name's Lisa, by the way!" I heard her screech back. Yeah, well that's fine and all, but I really don't care. I was so annoyed, I almost didn't want to give her a proper introduction. But of course, I knew that this would be too harsh, so I went right into it; of course the passion was all out of it.

"I'm Trent, of course. Trent Davies, I'm sure you've heard of me before.." I forced a shine of those pearly whites, and a wink too. I admit, I'm a bit too generous.

"No! I've never heard of you. But it's nice to meet you!" Oh come on! There was clearly something wrong with the girl. Was this her first time here? Well, by the looks of it yes, she was running into the junk section of the mall, where all the kiddie and useless stores were located. Hell, I haven't been back there since a long while.

"You lost, sweetheart?" I asked her, trying to help her mixed up mind.

"No, I think it's around here somewh... oh there it is! Come on!" She finally let go of my arm (damn, my sleeve was practically ruined by all that tugging, not to mention that it left a bit of pain in my arm). She dashed into a small store like the little crazy sprite she was, and I decided that I'd gone all the way here, so I casually walked on inside too. Then I noticed where we were.

The junk store, the place that didn't even, or really never had, belonged in the mall. Owned by that old fart with the thick glasses, white mustache; the fool who hadn't noticed in twenty years that no one - especially the teenagers of the mall - cared about old, beat up parts. Yet here he was, selling to no one and wondering why "no one is coming to buy anything?" I'll tell you why, doc - You're a failure. A loser who should never have gotten into the business in the first place. Kids don't want junk, they want CDs, soda, junk FOOD; but of course he wouldn't of known that now would he?

Passed the "watchful eye" of the shopkeep, Lisa was digging through a barrel of old engines. She really wasn't like much other girls was she? And I meant that in the worst way possible. While she did whatever the hell she was doing with those engines, I sat down on one of the rickety old chairs and wondered why the hell I was even here in the first place.

"Yeah, I ... I think this is it ..." Looking over at her, she had a chunk of greasy metal, barely even shiny in her hands. Did she know what to do with that thing, or was she gonna spray paint it silver and use it as a UFO for this crazy "movie" of hers.

"What in the hell is that?"
"It's an engine made with DLC, I think. It should ward off ..." She was talking about that crap again... ugh... give me a break! I green, if i have to hear one more green word about that stuff, I'm leaving! I don't green to help or green. Green. All I know is green. All I live is green. Green will help me now.

Green. "Are you green about these shoes? They're really comfortable? Because last time I bought Arnold, that's my husband, a pair he didn't like them. And I just green to be sure that ..." I didn't know why. But I felt good. But of course, taking one quick look could tell me why. It was ... uh, Ma'am. She was my best customer. Always blah blah blah, but she ate up my pitches like a hobo takes a handout. There it was, her hopeful, sad look. And here it was, my quick wit had memorized and preprocessed a new pitch just exactly for this situation.

"Of course they're fine, Ma'am. In fact, my uncle used to have a pair of these shoes. Do you know what he said about them ..." Always that same look of awe, ".. the damn finest shoes he'd ever bought. True that! In fact..."

The pitch flowed from me naturally, I'd have this sale wrapped up in no time. I wasn't irritated. That was an odd thought. But of course I wasn't, what was there to be irritated about? All there was was me and my customer. And it was ....sale time!

I couldn't believe I was doing this. How dumb does this look? I glared back at my insane accomplice one last time before I quickly hovered the piece over his bald head. Nothing happened. I hope not; this feels so dumb to just say "yeah" to her orders, like a damn dog. Maybe it's cuz I love her? Naw. I barely met the chick. Got the hots for, hell yeah. But love, that's nuts. My place, though? Damn, she's fast isn't she? Wonder what she'll want to see next.

We moved through the crowds of the mall, still heavy with people who're probably enjoying their damn nights instead of worrying. I wonder if it's be better to never have met her? I wouldn't have to be worrying about this insane bull***, but what if it's real? Then all these suckers are gonna die, aren't they? Die, or get their mind controlled. I guess it's better I know, just so that I can do something about this crap. I can live it up once this ****'s over. We get in my truck and drive to my place, the streets are littered with minivans and small convertibles stuck in the night traffic. We drive through the mess until we reach my home.

Actually, before we got home I could see something staring me right in the face. Not actually staring, but something coming right at me - it was light. But not green light; I couldn't see any car in front of me, or anything above making it, so I just kept driving. But do you know what she did? She just grabbed the wheel right then and there, didn't ask me or anything. Hell, we almost crashed right into a lamp post, had i not regained perfect control with ease. I looked at that crazy ***** and began to yell,

"WHat the **** do you think you're do..." She just pointed behind us, smugly, with some ulterior knowledge. As I turned I saw a black Mustang get swallowed up by the blue light. ****! The blue then died down, leaving nothing there. I was gonna ask her a billion questions about what the hell just happened, but she told me to drive. Seeing another blue light near us, I did just as she said.

When we got home I ran upstairs like a sprinter on crack and collapsed on my bed, my face buried in the silky sheets, mind drained, in the darkness of my apartment. I could hear her beginning to work on those helmets as she said, making a loud noise about every three seconds. I guess it dawned on me here; this is the end. Aliens, mind control, if this was real it could only be a dream or the end. That meant death. That meant afterlife. One good thing popped into my mind - Aunt Mildred - her big spectacles and grimy old hair and wrinkles under her eyes. I wanted to see her again. That's when I thought about my family. How are they? Were they experiencing the same crap as I was? God, I hoped not. Mom was old as it was, she didn't need all this **** to give her a heart attack. Damn ... I wished they were here, where I could see them.

I popped back up and found myself in my room, in the dark, with a basic stranger working on helmets and no one else in sight. I was alone here. So was my father. And my mother. The guilt was rattling my brain. The fear was overpowering it. I went to the TV to take my mind off of the chaos, but only saw bloodshed and blue lights. Horrific images of decapitated corpses and shadows of some creature, probably these damn aliens. I had no choice; I was not a dreamer, and I had to face up to the truth. I had to see how they were.

Reaching into my pocket I pulled out my cell phone and dialed a number. I waited for an answer. Finally I got one...

"Hello?"

"That there's a helmet made from Diamond Like Carbon.."

"Trent?!" It's like a shrill screech in my head. I shake from the noise. But then turn around to see there, walking amongst the stupid crowd Lisa, all hot, her clothes ripped in places exposing her more lovely figure underneath, glistening with sweat from this overhot sun beating down. And here she comes, towards me. It's kinda like in those sappy movies too, where the chick and the dude rush out to meet each other, calling each other's names. Only I ain't moving. I stand perfectly still, nervous and shocked as ****, as I wait for her to just come to me. I don't know, it's weird. The moment I have nothing left to do I take action, and the time I see the only woman I've known for the last few hours, who I can ask questions, who I can confide in, I totally go limp and act like I don't give a damn. Hmmm. A curious thing. But who really cares? The main damn thing is that we at least are together.

"Oh my God! I can't believe it's you, Trent! I thought..." she stopped her speech. Probably because the next few words would involve me sleeping with the fishes. But for some reason me down there bloody and dead made me chuckle. I'm no masochist or nothing, but I ain't dead neither. I just smirked, put my arm around the girl, clutching her firm stomach as I said,

"Yeah, we all thought it's the end. But... look at us here. Ha Ha. Now, babe, It's really great to see you and all. But can you tell me what the **** is going on here?"

"..uh..yeah." Her childish grin conformed back into adult apprehension as she began explaining what she, like so many of us, really understand only what they tell us. And hell, even most of that's a bunch of crap. Still, I tried to be as open-minded as I could. If what she told me was wrong, then oh well it's as good a guess as mine. But if it's right, then hell, we got us a real plan there. So I opened my ears,

"..well, I just basically got here too, you know. And like, just a few minutes ago it was night."
"Same here." I agreed.
"..Well, like, what they've been telling us, which really isn't anything, they like to keep secrets, just like .... uh, but, well they're saying that the blue, it took us... from ... well" she struggled to make sense, "we... all of us" she pointed, "who were in that apartment building have all experienced 'a Trans-temporal-spacial-shift." Huh. Fancy word I thought, in fact I even liked how it sounded. but the thing I didn't like was that it said something without explaining anything. It was like a waste of space.

"Ok, Lis', in English please. For us common folk."
"..uh, well that .. basically means, we all got transported from our place and time. It's" She started to look at her watch,
"Transported? Like teleported?"
"3:29 PM, approximately like a day later."
"A day later?"
"Yeah. Trent. It's... June 19th."
"How?" was all I could say. Yeah, well, it's not much. But given the circumstances.
"I... I really don't know that one. But you just gotta trust me I guess. That's what they're saying and, well it's like all we have to go on." Great the issue of trust, just what I needed. Now I've got even more questions to ask.
"Ok. I guess I can trust you." I grinned. She smiled back. I grabbed her dainty little hand and tried to get a grasp on the world. "I ... were you there when everyone started walking around like zombies. Cuz of the green light." She nodded and wanted to talk, but I continued, "I don't just mean a few people, but like everyone was marching down the streets."

"Yeah. Yeah, I heard. There's a lot of people who died because of the fighting that people did."
"Huh? What fighting? They didn't fight. They just shot up at the spaceships. It was crazy. Is there like a war going on here? Like between two groups of aliens or..."
"I don't know. But there are these aliens coming here." She smiled. But I didn't. All I could think of was that man with the pole through him again.
"****. I guess we all have to hide or something, huh?"
"What?" She asked, looking all innocent. I wondered if she had really seen that guy get killed like she said she had. If she did, she was really taking this oddly.
"The alien bastards! They're probably coming down to stop us from shooting at them or some.."
"No. No, these aliens are different," Lisa tried to explain, "they're like nice. I think they might have helped us because the other aliens are all gone now."
"Nice?" I contemplated that idea in my head a couple of times. But I still couldn't accept it. Lisa was willing to accept it. But I wasn't.
"I don't know. I wouldn't trust 'em. I think the best thing we can do is wear the helmets and like blast their brains out if..."
"I don't know about that Trent. That sounds really hostile."
"Well, ****, don't you think it was hostile of them to start ****ing with our heads and bodies like they did? ****, the reason we're in this mess is because we weren't prepared once. What about the next time?"
"But Trent, these guys are different. Totally different."
"I can't believe that." I said. I couldn't either. It was crazy. It was like they were still brain-washed. Hadn't they seen what they had done to us?
"Well... It's our only chance of hope. We should at least try to be nice. They could help." She was well-intended, I liked that. But foolish. Once again I felt different from everyone else here. I was the only one against the mob of aliens. But hell, maybe I was wrong here too. It wouldn't be the first time. Still.
"Whatever. You do what you want. I'm gonna go get some weapons."

I turned around. I looked up at the bright sky and thought of their huge ugly spaceships crashing down upon us like they had. Sneaking up on us and controlling us. I kept walking as Lisa rambled on about the aliens and how they're nice and ****, but I blocked it all out. At least until she said,

"..Pluma Beach." Those two words caught my interest and I turned around, facing her,
"What about Pluma Beach?"
"That's where we are, Trent!" She yelled.
"What? But that's in California."
"I know. So are we." I looked around, and saw behind us the large skyscrapers that decorated the city. It did look like Pluma. But ...
"I told you we were teleported here. In time and SPACE."
"But, my mom, she lives around here in Los Angeles. She..." I smiled like a little boy. My mom. She wasn't too far at all from here. I reached into my wet pockets but couldn't find my phone.

"Damn, must've dropped it or something... you got a phone?"
"Uh..no. I don't." I wanted to call my mom, make sure she was ok. And if she was, maybe I could go up and see her. At least she was my family, at least I could go out protecting my mom. Ha! I couldn't believe the sheer luck of my situation. I went over to one of the "tourists" in the crowd, and tapped him on the shoulder. He looked taken a back and a bit horrified with a taste of disgust upon seeing me, but I didn't care,

"Excuse me, could I use your phone?" I didn't even have to ask if he had one. I knew he did. All people like him had one readily available. The question was if he would...
"Uh... yeah, I guess." He murmured as he pulled out his dated phone and handed it over.

I then proceeded to call my mom, no answer, my uncle, no answer, any relatives I knew in Cali, but I didn't know those. It looked as though I would need to go up there to find out myself. And that would either be really stupid, or really brave. The two are so damn close anyways. I gave the sucker back his phone and went over to Lis',

"Uh, listen Lis' I might want to go and see my mom,"
"Oh, is she here?"
"Uh, yeah, sorta. She lives down in LA, and I wanted to see how she was."
"Oh, oh yeah. Sure. That sounds good. Is she ok?"
"Uh...I don't know. She didn't pick up the phone, so, I really don't know. She might not even be there."
"Oh, I'm sorry. I hope she's ok.."
"Yeah. Well, I'm gonna go see. Um, would you wanna go and..."
"Oh? Me? No, sorry. I gotta stay here, and wait for the aliens to come. Sorry, but I hope you find her. Uh," She looked as sad as I felt. I wonder why we even liked each other? We were nothing alike. But there it was. We both wanted the other to go with us. And it wasn't going to happen. "If you, if you have anytime left and you could make it in time, just like come here around ... 7PM or so. We could.. meet the aliens.."
"Uh.. yeah. We'll see. Thanks though."

I turned around, ready to leave to check on mom. Was about to leave Lisa, possibly for the last time ever. I was a mixed bag of mushy gushy emotions, but hell if I would show it. I was about to walk away when she said,

"Good luck. I hope you're ok." She smiled a little half-smile that was dipped in guilt and fear. I smiled a similar one and said,
"Yeah! Good luck with the aliens! Say hi for me!"

We both grinned and took one last look before...

1122211122221112111.content:
Walking through the crowds of confused huddling people, I could see that since I had left people were afraid, not just of the aliens, but of each other. The green, it must've done that to them. In every glaring eye I could see that guy who got beaten up by his own mother. I could see the guy who had been beaten up by his family. The world had gone mad, and now everyone was just starting to realize that. Welcome to my life. I didn't care what they thought, I was unlucky enough to have a brain during all of that green ****, and yes I saw the awful attrocities people commited, and yes I was a bit afraid that these alien scum might flip on their switch again. But I didn't have time to worry about that right now. I had to get to L.A.

The green. That reminds me. My ****ing helmet fell into the damn ocean. Looking back I knew it would be hard to find it alone. I'd have to go on without it. Grinding my teeth in anxiety, I passed by a rescue worker and tapped him on the shoulder. He seemed startled, "Huh?"

"I lost my helmet in the ocean when I fell out of my room,"
"Uh... okay. Alot of people lost alot of stuff when that big ass building got dropped.."
"Yeah. But this was really important. If you find it, it has some metal welded to the top, just give it to that girl over there," I pointed to Lisa, who was staring into the ocean.
"Uh.. sure buddy." He agreed, probably not even caring.

I nodded and then walked off this god-forsaken shore. I couldn't believe that I was going to go see my mom again. But my excitement was premature, I thought. I don't know what happened. What's happening down there in L.A. hell, I even forgot where to go it's been so long since I've been here. Some things were vaguely familiar, but I needed some real help. A cop was waiting in the distance, eating his lunch, I walked up to him and introduced myself,

"Hi officer," I grinned faintly, "I'm one of the people who fell out of that building," I pointed. But by the looks of his eyes, he didn't seem very amused, or interested, but I continued, "And I haven't been to L.A in a long time. Truthfully I'm from ..."
"So what?" He grunted.
"Well, I'm just saying that I've only been here when I was a boy, and I need some help finding out how to get back to L.A.." I tried explaining to this thick-headed..
"L.A?!" He exclaimed.

Yeah. What's wrong?"
"You don't wanna go back to L.A. You're better off here."
"No I have to go to L.A." I protested,
"That place is a deathtrap."
"...Why?" I was able to muster, after becoming unsettled at the damn images flashing through my mind. I didn't like the sound of deathtrap.
"It's closer east. It's closer to the ..." he stopped for a second, probably remembering that I hadn't been on the Earth for a bit. "... well, it's more prone to be get green waves shooting in and out of it. Green waves are hypnotic.." he blathered on probably not even believeing in it himself,
"I know what they are." I cut his lecture short, "I had a helmet that protected me from that."
"A helmet? Weren't you folks supposed to be from the past?" I nodded and he looked at me as though I was mad.
"Every place can get green waves," I explained, "unless you're wearing the helmet."
"Not these ones. They're stronger. Trust me you don't want to go in there. Hell half the city's probably dead.." He continued on, recounting the death, carnage, bloodshed, violence and horrors that had happened to L.A in the short frame I was gone. But I blocked it out. I didn't need to hear this. I already knew what he had meant, but I didn't care. I had gone all of this way so far by not listening to orders, the damn cops didn't help me so far, so why was I going to need to be told more horror stories. My mind was already made up.

"Look. I don't care who's dead and who's half-pole. I need to go back, are you gonna tell me how to go or not?"
"..... Right through that route. Just keep following it until you hit a sign that says 'Teddy Burger', that's when you wanna make a left,"
"Thanks." I reluctantly thanked him, even though he had been quite a prick.
"Just how do you plan on getting there? Walking?"

I hadn't thought of that. I guess I sorta figured that I'd just take my car and.. but it's about half-way across the country. I hate changes in plans. So I turned, and aksed,

"I haven't got a car. Could you take me?"
"Hell no!" He yelled, "Do I look stupid?! You wanna go get yourself killed, you do it on your own. I'm staying right here." He scowled at me. And I scowled back. I flipped the jackass off and walked away, wondering how in the hell would I get to see my mom again. But I kept on trying asking a couple of "tourists" what if I could catch a ride. No one let me. They were all too damn afraid of getting killed. It seemed as though I'd be stuck here, which I guess wasn't all bad, I'd get to see Lisa, kick those alien asses and get some well deserved revenge. Ah, but who gives a **** about that **** when your mom's life is on the ****ing line?! I sat down on the pavement and wallowed in my own ****ing pity.

Then I looked across from me, and what the hell do you know, I see a motorcycle with the keys sticking out of it. Looks like some dumb bastard was killed as he was about to get on. This looked like my chance. As I approached it, I looked around, afraid of being caught by that cop. At first I wasn't quite sure if this was the right thing to do, but soon enough my general fear was replaced by the urge to go and see my mom. I really didn't give a damn if I died in the process anymore, things were way too out of control already, I had to have at least some common thing. I got on the bike, and it brought memories flooding back of this punk chick I used to date a few years back. Damn, she was fine. I could see her now yelling "Come on Trenty, you gonna take it or what?" heh. Those were my more, heh, rebellious days. **** it. Why not? I tunred the key and road off, steadying myself, and trying to remember how to even ride this thing.

12.content:
Linda .... Linda Glorian ... the name sounds a bit familiar, but who was she? Oh, just your typical suburban mother who tries to do the best for her children in this muck of a world we live in. I mean, you can't watch TV anymore without hearing about a shooting, or the skyrocketing prices of gas. That's why I find it's best to have your children read. Of course they have to be good books, and not the trash schools try to fill their heads up with. Something clean and family friendly. Something sweet and gentle. Speaking of sweet, I hope little Jeremy, Miss Murphy's youngest boy, can play well with Todd.

He seems nice enough, those cute little shoes running around the house all day! I just hope he's not too active with Todd. You see, my Todd's not a runner, and he could get hurt with all that activity. That's what I've told Rachel, Rachel Murphy; I told her, they should play a fun board game like Checkers or Monopoly. It's never too early to learn how to run a successful business. Isn't that right, Rachel?

"Oh yeah, Linds, absolutely. My Tommy was a born accountant since he was three. He's so bright now, I wouldn't be surprised if he were president someday..." Rachel took a sip out of her glass, and I had to agree. This was turning out to be quite a lovely evening. From the sitting room downstairs you could watch the boys in the yard play, make sure they're alright. You never knew, even in a small quiet well renowned neighborhood like Elmester Heights. The boys were playing something outside now, I tried to tell them to play indoors, but boys will be boys, I say. Besides it's too lovely of an evening to spoil it with yelling.

"Linds, did you hear about Samantha?" That perked my ears up from their pleasurable stupor. Samantha was a petite little thing, a few blocks down. To tell the truth, she and her dog of a husband were the talk of the town these days. They always fought, and her loud, obnoxious crying could be heard from very far away, even with the windows closed! I had heard the rumor about her recently from Ethel, and I already knew what Rachel was about to say.

"She's finally decided to move out! Take the kids and go stay with her mother," Hmm. I hadn't heard of this before. I wondered if it were true. She didn't really seem like the type who could stand up for herself. Maybe the poor thing had finally had enough.

"Well, good for her!" Linda applauded quietly, gracefully. "It's about time she left him. How does he feel about it?"
"He's furious ... heard he didn't come home at all last night. I heard from Ethel that he might have ..."

But Rachel couldn't continue on as she heard in the little garden, loud, excessive crying coming from a little boy. It was Todd who was crying. It struck a chord in Linda's heart to hear such a noise. How long had he been going for, she wondered. Was he alright? She looked over at Rachel's worried face, and narrow eyes staring at Linda, waiting for her to go see what was wrong. But Todd always cried didn't he? She had glanced out quickly to see him playing with Jeremy still. He had probably lost; he always cried when he lost a game. Jeremy looked happy, it couldn't be too bad. But something in her told her that she had to do something. Linda ...

13.content:
Carlos ... Carlos Renuelas .... the name reminded me of someone, but, I don't think I know him. Who was he? He's a trucker, fella, and that's just what he'll stay as. Been a freelance driver since I got my license those years ago. And through all of them twist and turns, things have turned out alright. Not the best, but life's manageable, and that's all I need. Peggy Sue underneath me, and a big haul in back of her. Just picked up a shipment of Estelle Sugar, and afore I drop it off at its destination some 160 miles away, I want to give Peggy and me a small rest. Heck, may even see that girl inside the diner again. Now, if I could only remember her name...

"Be good to her, Doc." I give a half-grin to that little springy fella who pumps her blood into her. Damn its getting pricey too, but I guess that's what living's all about. Making it through the rough patches to sail on the clear open water. Speaking about drinks, I can't wait to guzzle down a few mugs and maybe order a pie or two, depends on how hungry I am.

Walking inside I see all the regulars, including that perfect little smile that greets me at the door. I look down, sly-like, hope she don't think I'm gazing a gander down at her. Charlotte, damn right. That's the girl's name. Charlotte, honey, I swear to you, we're getting married one day. Can't be the biggest thing, but who needs big. Damn, I really hope she ain't one of those girls who needs big. Economy's slow right now, and besides, a park beats out a ritzy church any old day of the week. Damn, she has a cute little smile, and those sparkling green eyes ain't too bad neither.

"Hey, C.R, how're things going with the business?" She harps like an angel.
"Oh, so so. Got a shipment of sugar going up to Reston City MegaMall."
"Dang, I always loved that place!" I know, I think. I heard her talk about how her and her sister ran away from home and stayed up there for a while. Well, hell, this time there could be some better circumstances. And a hell of a better ending. Should I ask her though? She was on duty, and she wouldn't want to go with a slob like me, now would she? Looking at her again, I can see her eyes glancing around the other fellows in the room. Well, she's a free woman, she's bound to look at others I 'spose. Better just order something quick, and get on with the job.

"Uh, I'll have a heavy chocolate shake, and a ch.... make that three cherry pies."
"Alright, C.R, Three red disks and a dirt sundae coming right up."

At least I'm getting more work than last week, that's always a good thing. But boy does Charlotte look good in that skirt. Too bad she couldn't go...

"Alright Huck, I'm gonna get off for the day, if that's alright?"
"Sure, darling, you've done quite enough for today."
Charlotte walked over to the back, hung up her work clothes, and put on a large dark sweater. She almost always worked later than this, it was odd to see otherwise.

"Hey, Charlotte? You getting off so early?" Carlos asked her.
"Oh yeah, switched my shifts so that I work earlier, and get out earlier. I forgot to tell you about that didn't I, C.R? Sorry." Dang! Things seemed just about perfect now. Could I ask her to come with me? Would it even be a wise thing to do?

"Hey, Charlotte!" I hollered out after her before she walked out the door. She turned her stream of red hair, and gazed straight at me...

14.content:
Amy ... Amy Hashimoto ... I didn't remember much about her. I didn't even know who she was... who was she? Ugh. No one does. I'm like, on the outside of the regular world. I'm a shadow creeping down the path that you barely notice until ... bam! You feel a bump in your head the next morning. Ha Ha. But I don't have time for introductions and stuff, I have to check out this house! It's creepy. And not just that regular odd feeling of creepy, this has a definite menacing feeling to it. Look! I think I saw something move inside!

"Well, it could be owned, you know." That's my older brother, John. John's a real drip when it comes to investigating. The only reason I bring him along is ... uh ... because he has a functioning camera. Yeah. Otherwise I could probably do this myself. I mean, he doesn't believe in anything, and he's such a coward. But company's company. A brother's a brother.

"Owned? No way that place is owned. I mean, who owns it the Adams Family? The Munsters? Give me a break John, that place has murder mystery written all over it."
"Amy, this isn't a book you know. You're not a junior sleuth!" John tried to diminish and extinguish my efforts, as he always did, but this time I would not be rattled. I had finally seen something truly odd in our little town ... and I had to get to the bottom of what was going on! I had definitely seen something move inside - something big, and probably hairy. I shuttered at the thought. I looked over at John, who was shaking in his boots.

"Come on John! Let's go in and investigate!" I ran ahead while John stayed there probably whimpering. I heard him yell something after me,

"Don't do it, Amy! It's dangerous!" I laughed in the face of danger! Ha Ha! I ran up to the heavy metal fence, and hid behind some particularly itchy bushes. I crouched down, pulled out my digital camera and looked into the highest window in the house. It was open, no curtain or anything, a perfect chance for catching something. I could hear John coughing behind me and said to him, without taking my eyes away from the window,

"Shh! Be quiet, John! And sit down! I don't want you to scare them away!"
"But Amy..." He began to whine again, but something was happening,
"Shhh! There it is!" I caught a glimpse of a small stout shadow roaring across the upstairs planks and snapped a few photos. Then it was gone. This was so exciting, nothing like this had ever happened before in the little town of Red Grove! I was so giddy I could almost hug John, but I didn't. I ran up to the gate, and began wondering how I could go in. The most obvious way would be to climb. But the spikes at the top looked frighteningly real. I didn't really want to risk my life. Maybe, I could ...

"forget this, I'm telling mom!" John whined as he ran away. What a chicken! How could he ... darn! I'd be grounded again! But I couldn't let this thing get away ... but how would I get in?
